bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 18, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses his conversation with Cornwell and the changes that are planned for the yellow fever painting. Hench may take the preliminary sketches to Cuba with him if he likes.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 18, 1941
div1.opener:
John Wyeth V Brother
Incorporated
Manufacturing Chemists,
Philadelphia
1600 Arch Street
February 18, 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
As I wrote you yesterday, I had dinner with
Mr. Cornwell last evening, and explained in detail the reason for
the suggested change on the Yellow Fever picture. Mr. Cornwell was
somewhat upset to begin with but after he thoroughly understood
what we were driving at, he became enthusiastic about the oppor-
tunity to paint a more dramatic situation.

As I told you when Mr. Withington and I were
at your home, I was afraid that the down light which he expected to
use in the patio could not be had honestly if the men were on the
porch of the officers' quarters; however, Cornwell made the suggest-
ion that we use the porch of the officers' quarters as a background,
putting Kissenger and Moran on the porch, or sitting on the porch
rail, and place the balance of the group in front of the porch,
where the down light of the late afternoon would be perfect. By
doing this he feels he can work in a little more landscape and a
little more tropical shrubbery. In all other details, he will be
very glad to paint the picture as you described it.

He says he may not be able to get as good a like-
ness of Lazear with his head bent down over the arm of Carroll; how-
ever, he says that any man who wears whiskers is much easier to paint
than one who does not, and inasmuch as Lazear was the only man of the
group who had them, he will be instantly identified. As to Reed and
Finley, he can use them in exactly the poses of which he now has
photographs and drawings.

I promised Mr. Cornwell that if you came through
New York on your way to Havana some time in March, I would bring you
up to the studio. The painting should be pretty well along by that
time but not so far along but that further suggestions will still be
possible, providing they don't involve any radical change. I myself
am very anxious to have you see the picture in progress.

As to the sketches, Mr. Cornwell has agreed to
work over the features on both sketches which you saw, and if you wish
to do so, you can have them both when you go to Havana. If you find
they are interested in them and would like to have one, or perhaps
even both of them, you can bring them back with you and we will be
glad to cooperate in holding out on the Cubans, so that when they do
get them they will appreciate them. In the meantime, perhaps you can
get something out of them that you want.

As to Kissenger and Moran, would it be possible
for you to get me photographic copies of any pictures which you have
of both these men, which were taken at or about the time of the
Yellow Fever study? Undoubtedly there is a photographer in Rochester
who would be good at making a copy of any or several of these. Nat-
urally we will be glad to pay all expense involved. Cornwell is
going ahead with the new sketch or sketches and will hold off paint-
ing any features on these two men until after we have gotten fairly
good likenesses. If you believe it will be necessary for me to write
to Mr. Kissenger or Mr. Moran to get this material, I will do so, but
will wait until I hear from you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, JOHN WYETH & BROTHER, INC.
George G. Kellogg
Advertising Director. GEX:HR
